title: What is AI, Really?
body:
AI: The Simple Definition

Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to computer systems designed to mimic human intelligence to perform specific tasks. Think of AI as an advanced tool that can see patterns, make decisions, or create content based on the data it's been trained on.

Key Point: Today, we exclusively use Narrow AI, meaning the system is only intelligent within a highly focused domain.

  • Narrow AI (Current): This is highly specific AI designed to perform a single, focused task.
    • Relatable Examples: AI software that reviews thousands of legal documents to find every instance of a specific contract clause, or an advertising platform that automatically adjusts bidding strategy.
  • General AI (Hypothetical): This would be an AI that can understand, learn, and apply its intelligence to solve any problem, just like a human being.

The key difference between these technologies is the ability to learn and adapt:

  • Traditional Software follows explicit rules written by a programmer (the rules are fixed).
    • Example: A simple quiz application that scores based on pre-programmed correct answers.
  • Automation performs repetitive, defined steps without learning (the steps are predictable).
    • Example: A mail-merge tool that automatically fills in a customer's name and company in an email template.
  • AI learns from data and feedback to improve its own rules and performance over time (the rules are adaptive).
    • Example: A system that learns your writing style and suggests structural improvements or alternative phrasing.

To function, AI systems need two things: data and a model. The core mechanism is Pattern Recognition.

Data is the Fuel

AI learning starts with massive amounts of dataâ€”this is the training set. For example, a system trained to assist a teacher is fed thousands of previously graded exams and essays.

Pattern Recognition: The Core Mechanism

  1. Prediction: Based on the patterns it learned, the AI model calculates the most statistically probable or appropriate output (e.g., suggesting a score, drafting a summary).
  2. Feedback & Refinement: Humans or the system itself evaluate the output. If the prediction was wrong, the system subtly adjusts its internal settings to make a better prediction next time. This process is called iteration.

title: Lawyer: E-Discovery/Document Review
body: The AI is trained on thousands of past litigation documents to recognize patterns associated with relevance (e.g., all emails referencing "unauthorized payment" or "confidential"). It quickly flags millions of documents for human review.

The power of these use cases comes from AI's incredible Speed & Scale, processing vast data instantly. However, this power comes with inherent limitations that demand careful human interaction:

  • Weakness: Lacks Context/Common Sense: AI focuses on patterns in the data, not real-world meaning or causality.
  • Weakness: Prone to Hallucinations: Generative AI predicts the most likely next word, which often results in outputs that sound plausible but are factually incorrect or fabricated.
  • Weakness: Data Dependency & Bias: If the training data is biased, incomplete, or contains errors (Garbage In, Garbage Out / GIGO), the AI will replicate and amplify that bias.
